description.p: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.

remarks.p:
The customer will be responsible for displaying a system use notification banner to users. A successful control response will need to address the conditions under which the banner will be displayed (if a non-government user accesses the system, the system use notification banner may not be appropriate), as well as the contents of the notification message.
In context of CoreOS, a banner must be displayed for all means of accessing CoreOS itself (e.g. service consoles, remote access through SSH, etc).
A control response to AC-8 is planned. Progress can be tracked via:
https://issues.redhat.com/browse/CMP-125

description.p: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.

remarks.p:
The customer will be responsible for displaying the use notification banner until the user acknowledges the usage condition and takes explicit actions to further access the system. A successful control response will need to address the means by which the user will indicate acknowledgement and move forward.
A control response to AC-8 is planned. Progress can be tracked via:
https://issues.redhat.com/browse/CMP-125

description.p: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.

remarks.p:
The customer will be responsible for displaying a system use information message to users. A successful control response will need to address the conditions under which the message will be displayed (if a non-government user accesses the system, the system use information message may not be appropriate), as well as the contents of the notification message, including references to applicable monitoring, recording, or auditing, and authorized usage of the system.
A control response to AC-8 is planned. Progress can be tracked via:
https://issues.redhat.com/browse/CMP-125

description.p: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.

remarks.p:
The customer will be responsible for determining the conditions under which the system use notification will be displayed. These conditions must be reviewed and accepted by the FedRAMP JAB.
A control response to AC-8 is planned. Progress can be tracked via:
https://issues.redhat.com/browse/CMP-125

description.p: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.

remarks.p:

A control response to AC-8 is planned. Progress can be tracked via:
https://issues.redhat.com/browse/CMP-125

description.p: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.

remarks.p:
The customer will be responsible for verifying that the system use notification is being displayed as required, either through a configuration baseline check or via other means. If this verification does not happen through a configuration baseline check, the JAB must review and accept the process used to perform the verification.
A control response to AC-8 is planned. Progress can be tracked via:
https://issues.redhat.com/browse/CMP-125

description.p: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.

remarks.p: Regardless of access mechanism, such as the CoreOS Console or remote access attempts through SSH, unauthenticated users will only be shown the system use notifications (as defined in AC-8) and login prompt. This is non-configurable behavior.

description.p: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.

remarks.p:
CoreOS was designed to satisfy the audit requirements outlined in the Configuration Annex to the Protection Profile for General Purpose Operating Systems available at https://www.niap-ccevs.org/Profile/PP.cfm.
Specifically, the minimum auditable events included:
| Configuration Action | CNSSI 1253 Value or DoD-specific Value | NIAP Reference | | Audit All Logons (Success/Failure) and Logoffs (Successful) | Authentication events: (1) Logons (Success/Failure); (2) Logoffs (Success) | FAU_GEN.1.1.c | | Audit File and Object Events (Unsuccessful) | File and Objects events: (1) Create (Success/Failure); (2) Access (Success/Failure); (3) Delete (Success/Failure); (4) Modify (Success/Failure); (5) Permission Modification (Success/Failure); (6) Ownership Modification (Success/Failure) | FAU_GEN.1.1.c | | Audit User and Group Management Events (Success/Failure) | User and Group Management events: (1) User add, delete, modify, disable, enable (Success/Failure); (2) Group/Role add, delete, modify (Success/Failure) | FAU_GEN.1.1.c | | Audit Privilege or Role Escalation Events (Success/Failure) | Privilege/Role escalation (Success/Failure) | FAU_GEN.1.1.c | | Audit All Audit and Log Data Accesses (Success/Failure) | Audit and log data access (Success/Failure) | FAU_GEN.1.1.c | | Audit Cryptographic Verification of Software (Success/Failure) | - | FAU_GEN.1.1.c | | Audit Program Initiations (Success/Failure) | Application (e.g., Firefox, Internet Explorer, MS Office Suite, etc.) initialization (Success/Failure) | FAU_GEN.1.1.c | | Audit System Reboot, Restart, and Shutdown Events (Success/Failure) | System reboot, restart and shutdown (Success/Failure) | FAU_GEN.1.1.c | | Audit Kernel Module Loading and Unloading Events (Success/Failure) | - | FAU_GEN.1.1.c |
Additionally, CoreOS was designed to satisfy the audit requirements outlined in Intelligence Community Standard Number 500-27, "Collection and Sharing of Audit Data" (ICS 500-27) that were found to be applicable to operating systems performing as a container host. A copy of ICS 500-27 can be found at https://www.dni.gov/files/documents/FOIA/DF-2016-00213.pdf
Selected audit events from ICS 500-27 include: * Authentication events * Logons (Success/Failure) * Logoffs (Success) * File & Object Events * Create (Success/Failure) * Access (Success/Failure) * Delete (Success/Failure) * Modify (Success/Failure) * Permission Modifications (Success/Failure) * Ownership Modifications (Success/Failure) * User & Group Management events * User add, delete, modify, suspend, lock (Success/Failure) * Group/Role add, delete, modify (Success/Failure) * Use of Privileged/Special Rights events * Security or audit policy changes (Success/Failure) * Configuration changes (Success/Failure) * Admin or root-level access (Success/Failure) * Privilege/Role escalation (Success/Failure) * Audit and log data accesses (Success/Failure) * System Reboot, Restart & Shutdown (Success/Failure) * Application (e.g. Netscape, IE, Lotus Notes, etc) initialization (Success/Failure)

remarks.p: Coordinating the security audit function with other organizational entities is outside the scope of system configuration.

description.p: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.

remarks.p:
Red Hat did not express judgement in the rationale for why auditable events are deemed to be adequate to support after-the-fact investigations of security incidents.
For rationale regarding why the auditable events are deemed to be adequate to support after-the-fact investigations of security incidents, please contact your countries Common Criteria representative:
https://www.commoncriteriaportal.org/ccra/members/

description.p: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.

remarks.p:
Determination of which events are to be audited within CoreOS from the subset of auditable events defined in AU-2(a) is an organizational control outside the scope of CoreOS configuration guidance.
Should system operators decide to use the NIST National Checklist for OpenShift 4.x, all events identified in AU-2(c) are selected to be audited.
Additionally, in regards to the AU-2(d) requirement of defining "the frequency" of auditing for each identified event, it should be noted that the CoreOS audit subsystem generates audit events in realtime (e.g. immediately upon an audited event occurring).

description.p: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.

remarks.p:
AU-3 is satisfied when the following configuration checks have been implemented: * CCE-82463-1: Enable auditd Service
These configuration checks are enabled in the NIST National Checklist for OpenShift 4.x.

description.p: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.

remarks.p: By default, CoreOS auditing uses the internal system clocks to generate time stamps for audit records. At the code level, this is accomplished through the use of the C programming language time.h which is part of the C Standard Library.

description.p: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.

remarks.p:
By default, the CoreOS auditing records time stamps for audit records that can be mapped to Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). For example in the following node audit record:
type=SYSCALL msg=audit(1364481363.243:24287): arch=c000003e syscall=2 success=no exit=-13 a0=7fffd19c5592 a1=0 a2=7fffd19c4b50 a3=a items=1 ppid=2686 pid=3538 auid=1000 uid=1000 gid=1000 euid=1000 suid=1000 fsuid=1000 egid=1000 sgid=1000 fsgid=1000 tty=pts0 ses=1 comm="cat" exe="/bin/cat" subj=unconfined_u:unconfined_r:unconfined_t:s0-s0:c0.c1023 key="sshd_config" type=CWD msg=audit(1364481363.243:24287): cwd="/home/shadowman" type=PATH msg=audit(1364481363.243:24287): item=0 name="/etc/ssh/sshd_config" inode=409248 dev=fd:00 mode=0100600 ouid=0 ogid=0 rdev=00:00 obj=system_u:object_r:etc_t:s0 nametype=NORMAL cap_fp=none cap_fi=none cap_fe=0 cap_fver=0 type=PROCTITLE msg=audit(1364481363.243:24287) : proctitle=636174002F6574632F7373682F737368645F636F6E666967
The msg field records a time stamp and a unique ID of the record in the form audit(time_stamp:ID). Multiple records can share the same time stamp and ID if they were generated as part of the same Audit event. The time stamp is using the Unix time format - seconds since 00:00:00 UTC on 1 January 1970.
See https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_enterprise_linux/8/html/security_hardening/auditing-the-system_security-hardening for more example and explanation of auditing.

description.p: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.

remarks.p:
Configuration management is enforced through Ignition configurations and Operators.
Ignition is the utility that is used by Red Hat Enterprise Linux CoreOS (RHCOS) to manipulate disks during initial configuration, confirming all new machines meet the declared configuration.
Ignition is meant to initialize systems, not change existing systems. After a machine initializes and the kernel is running from the installed system, the Machine Config Operator from the OpenShift Container Platform cluster completes all future machine configuration.
Operators are a method of packaging, deploying, and managing a Kubernetes application. Watching over the CoreOS environment, using its current state to make decisions in real time, the Machine Config Operator (MCO) manages updates and configuration changes to essentially everything between the kernel and kubelet.
For additional information: https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/latest/architecture/architecture-rhcos.html#rhcos-about_architecture-rhcos https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/latest/operators/olm-what-operators-are.html https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/latest/nodes/nodes/nodes-nodes-managing.html https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/latest/installing/install_config/installing-customizing.html

remarks.p: Ensuring that the organization uses software and associated documentation in accordance with contract agreements and copyright laws is the complete responsibility of the organization. Red Hat's responsibilities to assist with the tracking of software licensing and usage of software provided by Red Hat will be fulfilled in accordance with all applicable contracts and agreements established for the project with the organization.

description.p: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.

remarks.p:
Tracking the use of software and associated documentation protected by quantity licenses to control copying and distribution is an organizational control outside the scope of CoreOS.
For CoreOS nodes operating in an OpenShift environment, the OpenShift Cluster Manager (OCM) service acts as a bridge to Red Hat Subscription Manager. A cluster connected to the internet can send telemetry to OpenShift Cluster Manager at https://cloud.redhat.com/openshift/, which then handles integration with Red Hat Subscription Manager to track subscriptions for OpenShift clusters.
For disconnected clusters utilizing CoreOS, there is no way to send telemetry data to OpenShift Cluster Manager. In this case, the organization must manually register their disconnected clusters with OpenShift Cluster Manager following the instructions at https://access.redhat.com/solutions/4930131

description.p: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.

remarks.p: Controlling and documenting the use of peer-to-peer file sharing technology to ensure that this capability is not used for the unauthorized distribution, display, performance, or reproduction of copyrighted work is an organizational control outside the scope of CoreOS configuration.

remarks.p:
Developing an organization-level contingency planning policy is outside the scope of CoreOS configuration.
To facilitate a control response and assist in contingency planning, CoreOS nodes should not contain any stateful information as stateful information should exist only in etcd and get persisted to OCP nodes via operators. Because of this, CoreOS nodes can be added/removed as necessary to fully recover/restore the CoreOS environment.

remarks.p:
The customer will be responsible for conducting daily incremental and weekly full backups of user-level information contained in the information system. Additional requirements and guidance include maintaining at least three backup copies of user-level information (at least one of which is available online) or provides an equivalent alternative. A successful control response will detail how backups of user-level information occurs, and how three backup copies are maintained.
Conducting backups of user-level information to include the backups of a centralized identity provider is an organizational control outside the scope of CoreOS configuration.
CoreOS nodes should not contain any stateful information as stateful information should exist only in etcd and get persisted to OCP nodes via operators. Because of this, CoreOS nodes can be added/removed as necessary to fully recover/restore the CoreOS environment.
To assist System Administrators and organizations in their control response, documentation about backing up CoreOS user-level information stored in etcd in OpenShift nodes can be viewed at:
https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/latest/backup_and_restore/backing-up-etcd.html
Node handling such as adding and removing CoreOS nodes can be viewed at:
https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/latest/nodes/nodes/nodes-nodes-working.html

description.p: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.

remarks.p:
The customer will be responsible for conducting daily incremental and weekly full backups of system-level information contained in the information system. Additional requirements and guidance include maintaining at least three backup copies of system-level information (at least one of which is available online) or provides an equivalent alternative. A successful control response will detail how backups of user-level information occurs, and how three backup copies are maintained.
Conducting backups of system-level information is an organizational control outside the scope of CoreOS configuration.
CoreOS nodes should not contain any stateful information as stateful information should exist only in etcd and get persisted to OCP nodes via operators. Because of this, CoreOS nodes can be added/removed as necessary to fully recover/restore the CoreOS environment.
To assist System Administrators and organizations in their control response, documentation about backing up CoreOS system-level information stored in etcd in OpenShift nodes can be viewed at:
https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/latest/backup_and_restore/disaster_recovery/about-disaster-recovery.html
Node handling such as adding and removing CoreOS nodes can be viewed at:
https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/latest/nodes/nodes/nodes-nodes-working.html

description.p: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.

remarks.p:
The customer will be responsible for conducting daily incremental and weekly full backups of information system documentation including security-related documentation.
Conducting backups on information system and security-related documentation is an organizational control outside the scope of OpenShift configuration.

description.p: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.

remarks.p:
The customer will be responsible for protecting the confidentiality, integrity, and available of backup information at storage locations. Additional requirements and guidance include determining what elements of the cloud environment require the Information System Backup control. The customer will determine how Information System Backup is going to be verified and appropriate periodicity of the check.
Protecting the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of backup information at separate storage locations an organizational control outside the scope of OpenShift configuration.

description.p: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.

remarks.p:
The customer will be responsible for documenting how to reconstitute their CoreOS environment. A successful control response will detail processes used to fully recover/restore the CoreOS environment.
CoreOS nodes should not contain any stateful information as stateful information should exist only in etcd and get persisted to OCP nodes via operators. Because of this, CoreOS nodes can be added/removed as necessary to fully recover/restore the CoreOS environment.
To assist System Administrators and organizations in their control response, documentation about disaster recovery procedures for CoreOS nodes in OpenShift can be viewed at:
https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/latest/backup_and_restore/disaster_recovery/about-disaster-recovery.html
Node handling such as adding and removing CoreOS nodes can be viewed at:
https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/4.5/nodes/nodes/nodes-nodes-working.html

remarks.p: The customer will be responsible for analyzing their CoreOS deployment for flaws, reporting on those flaws, and correcting them. A successful control response will include a discussion of the process by which flaws are discovered and remediated, as well as tools that are used to assist in detection and remediation.

description.p: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.

remarks.p: The customer will be responsible for testing CoreOS updates related to flaw remediation prior to installation. A successful control response will discuss the testing process (e.g. the nature of the test environment, the types of testing performed, the tools in testing, etc.).

remarks.p: The customer is responsible for ensuring that they employ malicious code protection at information system entry, and exit points to detect and eradicate malicious code. A successful control response will need to address use of code protection mechanisms to protect assets from malicious software (i.e. Viruses, malware, rootkits, worms, and scripts). In regards to CoreOS, this is generally through the use third party tools.

description.p: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.

description.p: Describe how is the software component satisfying the control.

remarks.p: Blocking malicious code, quarantining malicious code, sending alerts to administrator, or some other organization-defined action in response to malicious code detection is an organizational control outside the scope of CoreOS configuration.
